(since you'll often want to work in multiple namespaces) and
no longer create a blackboard by default. The snapshot visitor

the visited path since behaviour ids no longer map directly
to blackboard ids. Tooling downstream will have to take into
account these changes.

data.author: Daniel Stonier
data.message:
minor fixes to 1.3.x (#240)

* [blackboard] no copying/pickling, just use handles

Copying, deepcopying often result in pickling happening, which will
almost always get you into trouble if you are storing objects on the
blackboard that are python bound (i.e. c/c++ under the hood).

Just use handles for now, it's eminently usable and tree ticks
as we have designed for here dont have to handle the concurrency issues.

* [composites] pulled up short on dropping the stop in tick here, just
comments

This is very confusing when children get terminated before they even
get a chance to initialise. Ostensibly, the parallel still needs
to reset the status of the children and it can probably do just
that, but not pulling the plug on it in this update just in case ...
there are consequences.

from outside the behaviour, but can't be passed in at init time.

The alternatives are less appealing.

data.message:
[behaviour] setup revamped (#148)

* setup() is strictly responsible for it's own behaviour now (like initialise, update, terminate).
* setup_with_descendants() has the responsibility for crawling
* BehaviourTree.setup() also assumes responsibility for crawling
* Timeout is catered for now at the application level (i.e. in BehaviourTree.setup()).

[meta] bugfix timeout decorators, fixes #38

They stopped triggering initialise() after #34. The key point here
is to manually trigger the initialise externally and let the underlying
initialise be triggered by the underlying behaviour. This needed
the alias to initialise in the imposter to be removed. It should
not be there after #34, but keep an eye that this does not break anything
else.

used inserted by other users in sentences.

data.author: Michal Staniaszek
data.message:
[rqt_behaviour_tree] new package for viewing behaviour trees

Currently has an undiagnosed segfault issue. Occurs whenever the tree is
updated, and sometimes arbitrarily. It happens sometime in the redraw_graph_view
function. Sometimes it's a segfault, sometimes multiple free. Seems to be
something to do with _scene.clear(). Removing that and replacing it with the
initialisation of the scene from the init function means that things aren't
displayed properly any more, but it no longer crashes. There is some mention of
the QTimer only being able to be run in the QThread, and the only place that is
used is in rqt_gui.main, as far as I can tell. Must be something to do with
elements being drawn again when they've been deleted, but can't get in there to
debug.

data.author: Michal Staniaszek
data.message:
[py_trees] output behaviour information to a logging topic

- Messages for behaviour and behaviour tree.
- Populate messages using the LoggingVisitor.
- Create a base class for visitors so that they all inherit from the same
  things. This allows control over some basic requirements. In particular,
  should be able to define whether a visitor looks at every node or just the
  running ones. In the case of logging, we want to visit all of the nodes and
  look at their information.
- Hacky implementation of different types of visitors.
- Use the unique_id package to generate and convert uuids.

data.author: Daniel Stonier
data.message:
[py_trees] nosetest fixes, sequence abort bugfix, behaviour update return guard and a new meta.

This fixes several problems. The nosetests were out of date, so this fixes them. It also
caught a bug in the sequence where it would set everything to invalid whenever it triggered the
abort function.

Adds a new guard to behaviour updates, catching when a users behaviour does not set a result,
or provides something that is not in enum Status.

And a new meta behaviour...failure is success, when you need to march on through a sequence
regardless.
